seo.metaTitle: NWA Daily - A daily newsletter about all things Northwest Arkansas
seo.metaDescription: NWA Daily is a daily email newsletter that keeps readers up to date on the latest Northwest Arkansas news or NWA news in events, restaurants, business,  the community, politics, art, entertainment, culture, and sports in Northwest Arkansas including news about Bentonville, Rogers, Springdale, and Fayetteville

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas Health Systems Look to Meet Growing Demand
posts.content:
Since a recent analysis of Northwest Arkansas revealed that nearly $240m spent on Medicare enrollee's healthcare went towards services provided outside of the region, local health systems have responded by expanding their facilities and partnering to offer more residencies.

  • Growing need: The findings suggest that demand is outpacing supply for healthcare providers in Northwest Arkansas as the population grows, giving the region's health sector a unique opportunity to expand and innovate.
  • Growing together: The NWA Council and healthcare providers are thinking outside the box to find solutions to these challenges; for instance, Mercy, UAMS, and Veterans Health Care System of the Ozarks have teamed up to train dozens of new internal medicine residents annually.

Read more on the story HERE.

posts.title: Cool Jobs in NWA
posts.content:
Looking for a job? Check out these positions posted to our community board:

  • Buddy Pegs is looking for a Retail Manager
  • Mount Sequoyah Center has an open position for a Development Director

Have a job you're looking to fill? Post it HERE!

posts.title: Artlook Streamlines School Access to Local Arts Organizations
posts.content:
Artlook, an online interactive map designed to connect Northwest Arkansas schools with arts education organizations, recently launched and has, so far, partnered with over 33 local organizations. 

  • Educational Tool: Artlook is an excellent resource for teachers who want to give students access to available resources but lack time to compile their own research. So far, the platform shows 150 schools are looking for art opportunities. 
  • Creating Opportunities: Arts organizations such as the Symphony of Northwest Arkansas and The Music Education Initiative are committed to providing educational events and exposing job opportunities in music and entertainment to younger students. 

Learn more about the Artlook platform HERE.

posts.title: Groundbreaking First Street Flats Project Begins In Downtown Rogers
posts.content:
First Street Flats, an upcoming apartment complex in downtown Rogers, recently held its groundbreaking ceremony. Completion is planned for spring 2024 – and it looks like the wait will be worth it. 

  • Renew: The complex repurposes parts of the old Ozark Cider & Vinegar Company building, transforming it into a multi-family community of 121 units, from studio size up to 2 bedrooms, and amenities like a plunge pool, co-working space, and coffee bar.
  • Sustain: Speaking of groundbreaking, First Street Flats will be one of Benton County's first net-zero housing communities, utilizing natural energy sources to provide enough power for this innovative community.

Learn more about the First Street Flats project HERE.

posts.title: Weekend Roundup
posts.content:
What are you doing this weekend? If you aren't sure yet, we've got you covered!

  • Foodies: Don't miss out on the great deals during the last few days of Fayetteville Restaurant Week.
  • Swing for the fences: No. 8 Arkansas Softball continues the Razorback Invitational this weekend with matchups scheduled against Drake and No. 19 Arizona.
  • Bring the pesticide: Only three chances left to catch Little Shop of Horrors, presented by Arkansas Public Theater in Downtown Rogers.
  • In business: A vibrant display of Northwest Arkansas's businesses, food, and music will be displayed during the Black-Owned Business Expo on Saturday, Feb 25, at the Fayetteville Town Center from 10-4p.
  • Record fast: Watch the No. 1 & No. 2 nationally ranked men's and women's Arkansas track & field teams set record speeds as they host the 2023 SEC Indoor Championships this weekend.
  • Musically: Curate a weekend of great live music experiences with KUAF's list of local shows around town this weekend.
  • Keep the beat: Celebrate Black History Month with a multicultural performance by the West African drum and dance company Afrique Aya at Springdale Public Library on Saturday, Feb 25, from 2-3p.
  • Off to market: Shop local goods at Fayetteville Farmer's Indoor Market on Saturday, Feb 25, from 11-3 at the Fayetteville Senior Center.

Enjoy your weekend, everyone!

node.headline: Living Net Zero And Meeting Art Heroes

posts.title: How NWA Is Taking On The Challenge Of Urban Runoff
posts.content:
The rapid growth of Northwest Arkansas has contributed to an increased urban stormwater runoff, leading to land loss through erosion and sedimentation of water sources. 

  • Changing course: Organizations in the area have implemented 12 best management practices, such as rain gardens and porous pavements, to reduce the effects of runoff. 
  • Working together: Counties are utilizing public education, outreach, and projects to raise awareness about the runoff issue and encourage preventive measures that can be taken before erosion leads to expensive damage. 

Learn more from this short episode of Ozarks at Large HERE.

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas Ranks Among World's Best Places to Bike
posts.content:
PeopleForBikes has released its 2022 Best Places to Bike list, with Northwest Arkansas's big-four cities ranking among the world's best places for cycling.

  • Southern bike bells: Bentonville, Rogers, Springdale, and Fayetteville earned above-average ratings for their access to bike networks, as well as rankings in the top five bikeable cities for the US South region. 
  • Intentionality: Criteria for making the Best Places to Bike List include offering practical strategies to improve biking, such as youth engagement, network connectivity, and trail development.

Explore the list and view interactive maps of your city's bike networks HERE.

posts.title: A Preview Of The Aronson Lifestyle Tonight At The 112 Drive-In
posts.content:
Alamo Drafthouse will host a special event tonight to commemorate the transformation of the 112 Drive-In with a screening of Universal Pictures' Cocaine Bear.

  • Movie-ing on: The new development from ITEX, called The Aronson, will replace the locally-beloved 112 Drive-In with modern amenities while preserving the spirit of the iconic film destination that served NWA for 42 years.
  • Film legend: Named after cinema pioneer and Arkansas-native Max Aronson, the cinema-inspired development will include over 200 multifamily units, a retail destination, and Arkansas's first Alamo Drafthouse Cinema + Drive-In. 

Learn more about The Aronson in About You HERE.

posts.title: Central Standard Talent Opens Its US Headquarters At Ledger
posts.content:
Central Standard Talent is excited to announce the opening of its US headquarters in Bentonville, integrating its Mexico-based operations with its new home in the Ledger Building. 

  • Tech haven: The team has been met with strong support from local and state leaders, highlighting Northwest Arkansas as an emerging leader in the tech sector. 
  • Locking in: CST offers a comprehensive solution, in conjunction with its sister company Metova, that enables clients to find and retain top talent while keeping ahead of the innovation curve. 

Read more about The Ledger's new occupant HERE.

posts.title: Fayetteville Restaurant Week Is Almost Over
posts.content:
Fayetteville Restaurant Week is almost over, so here are a few ideas to get the most out of this week before it ends!

  • The trifecta: Start the day with a hot scone or a corned beef sammie at The Hip Cafe, followed by a Delta Dog and a side of potato salad at Girls Gone BBQ for lunch, then settle into a three-course dinner at Mockingbird Kitchen. Sounds like the perfect food day.
  • Nightlife: Grab some friends and head out to Wine University, offering three different wines in a bottle-sized wine tower paired with a delicious charcuterie board for $30, or hit Big Box Karaoke for their $5 soba bowls!

Find more information and view participating restaurants HERE.

posts.title: Fayetteville Allocates $1.5M in ARPA Funds To Help With Rising Childcare Costs
posts.content:
Fayetteville is addressing the rising childcare costs by expanding its childhood assistance program with $1.5 million in ARPA funds dedicated to providing eligible recipients with up to 12 monthly payments for childcare.

  • Investing in care: The city's support for the industry is crucial to alleviating the high demand for childcare and hard-to-come-by staffing, often resulting in families being waitlisted for months.
  • Consider the cost: Childcare is often one of the most significant monthly expenses for families, impacting low-income families or those with multiple kids in childcare the most.

Read more on the story HERE.

posts.title: Tyson Foods & America's Car-Mart Among Top US Companies For Diversity
posts.content:
Northwest Arkansas-based Tyson Foods and America's Car-Mart each made Newsweek's America's Greatest Workplaces 2023 for Diversity, a list of 1,000 companies that received top scores from employees on respecting and celebrating diversity. 

  • Employees speak up: The list was compiled after gathering data from public sources, HR professionals, and a survey of 350,000 employees from large companies. 
  • Better business: Car-Mart CEO Jeffrey Williams shared that their commitment to inclusion "allows our associates to thrive, and also for us to deliver best-in-class products and services to our customers and communities."

See Newsweek's list HERE.

posts.title: Walmart Saw Biggest Sales Month In Company History Last Year
posts.content:
Walmart's FY23 Earnings Report revealed strong sales during the holiday season, with full-year sales up 6.7% compared to the prior year. 

  • Substantial numbers: Full-year revenue came in at $611b, with adjusted earnings per share at $6.29, both exceeding expectations. December was the biggest sales month in Walmart's history, led by food sales. 
  • Realistic forecast: With increasing interest rates and a shift in sales towards more budget-friendly options, the company expects a slowdown for the coming fiscal year. 

Read more from Talk Business & Politics HERE.

posts.title: New Facility Will Multiply Impact Of Samaritan Community Center
posts.content:
Samaritan Community Center has served the hurting and hungry in NWA with dignity and compassion for over two decades. In 2022, SCC served over 55,000 meals, provided over $600,000 in free dental care, and distributed 207,490 snack packs to NWA schoolchildren. 

  • New home base: The nonprofit plans to open a new 40,000 sqft facility at the corner of Pleasant Grove Rd and Hwy 71-B in Rogers, complete with a mental health counseling center, dental center, a teaching kitchen, 4-acre farm, and collaborative care center for free services and classes. 
  • The gift of growth: With 96% of funds raised for the $16.8m facility, doors should open by Sept 2023, so be on the lookout for an even more significant impact from Samaritan Community Center.

Donations are currently worth double, thanks to a challenge grant! Join the mission HERE.
posts.topic: Sponsored by Hark at Excellerate Foundation

posts.title: Cool Jobs in NWA
posts.content:
Looking for a job? Check out these positions posted to our community board:

  • Canopy is looking for a Development Manager or Director
  • Ropeswing has an open position for a General Manager

Have a job you're looking to fill? Post it HERE!

posts.title: PACRIDGE Brings Regenerative Farming To Northwest Arkansas
posts.content:
Canadaian-based Pacific Ridge is expanding operations to Northwest Arkansas, intending to bring regenerative soil-to-shelf farming practices to more farmers, retailers, and consumers with transparency and technology. 

  • Sustainability mission: The farmer-owned company and partners with the True Crops farming community to lead transformative environmental & corporate sustainability efforts and supply quality, sustainable plant-based foods, beverages, and ingredients.
  • Branching out: The headquarters of the company's US operations will soon open in Northwest Arkansas at a facility in North Rogers, and plans to hire a group of local talent in sales, marketing, EDI, and logistics to help grow PACRIDGE's influence in the States.

Read more on PACRIDGE's expansion HERE.

posts.title: NWA Gives Offers Free Training To Help NWA Nonprofits Maximize Impact
posts.content:
With a vision to see Northwest Arkansas become one of the most generous communities on earth, NWA Gives is hosting free training to prepare nonprofits to make the most of the upcoming NWA Gives Day on Apr 6.

  • Five years strong: Since 2018, NWA Gives has helped 300 participating nonprofits raise almost $3m, enabling them to accomplish their unique missions to serve our region.
  • Training day: Register now to attend a free one-day Intensive training on Feb 21 at Thaden Field, where you can learn from the experts at Branches Mission Lab on how to effectively market, communicate and fundraise for your nonprofit.

Space is limited; sign up for the free training HERE.

posts.title: Kian Lam Kho Shares The Code To Delicious Chinese Cooking at Meiji
posts.content:
Chef Kian Lam Kho, the author of Phoenix Claws and Jade Trees, will be a guest chef at Meiji Japanese Cuisine until Feb 25 as part of Fayetteville Restaurant Week.

  • From software to food: Growing up in Singapore, Chef Kian began his career as an aerospace engineer and software developer for Wall Street before eventually transitioning to pursue food and writing. 
  • Programming flavor: Like coding a computer program, Chef Kian enjoys experimenting with recipes and ingredients to deliver a unique dish, taking liberties to make them his own while preserving the different cultures behind them. 

Learn more about Chef Kian's journey and passion on this episode of Ozarks At Large HERE.

posts.title: Get a Taste of Nostalgia During Fayetteville Restaurant Week
posts.content:
Fayetteville Restaurant Week is in full swing, and restaurants like Theo's, Southern Food Co., East Side Grill, and more are throwing it back, returning some of your favorite dishes from past menus.

  • Duck, duck, booze: Bordinos Restaurant & Wine Bar has brought back their treasured Beet-It Martini and Duck Farfalle and will be offering wine flights or by-the-glass options!
  • Double stuffed: Bottle Rocket Subs has resurrected The Stuffy with all of its sliced turkey, balsamic bacon jam, and pimento cheesy goodness! Follow that up with a sweet dessert at Andy's and get the legendary Hog Heaven Jackhammer – an exclusive treat to NWA!

Find more information and view participating restaurants HERE.

posts.title: Forbes Ranks Arvest Bank Among America's Best Employers
posts.content:
Northwest Arkansas's Arvest Bank is among the 1,000 companies in the Forbes 2023 list of America's Best Large Employers.  

  • Word of mouth: The independent survey gathered responses from 45,000 American employees working within large companies, gauging their willingness to recommend their employer to friends and family.  
  • Winning streak: This is the second year in a row Arvest has been named to Forbes' list, as well as previous recognitions by Forbes, including the Best Employer for Diversity list in 2022 and World's Best Banks in 2022. 

Read the full story in Arkansas Money & Politics HERE.

posts.title: Experience the Vibrant Culture of Black-Owned Businesses in NWA
posts.content:
A vibrant display of Northwest Arkansas's businesses, food, and music will be on display this weekend during the Black-Owned Business Expo on Saturday, Feb 25, at the Fayetteville Town Center from 10-4p.

  • Face to face: The expo invites the public to interact with the businesses often featured by Black-Owned NWA, a social media company dedicated to spotlighting Black-owned businesses in NWA and the people behind them.
  • Open to the public: Admission to the expo is free, so whether you're a business owner or just a fan of goods and services, be sure to stop by, join the fun, and support local Black-owned businesses.

Follow Black-Owned NWA on Instagram for more updates HERE.

posts.title: XNA Takes Off Strong In 2023 Showing Impressive January Numbers
posts.content:
Northwest Arkansas National Airport recorded 62,354 passengers in January, achieving the second-best January in the airport's history. 

  • Second to one: The only time the airport saw more boardings in January was in 2020, which boarded a total of 67,306 passengers.
  • New heights: XNA is poised for an even better Febraury and March, with new nonstop service to Phoenix and Orlando via Breeze Airways on the horizon.

Take off with FareFlightNWA for more information HERE.

posts.title: U of A School of Art Unveils Cutting-Edge Studio And Design Center
posts.content:
The University of Arkansas's School of Art has officially opened its new Studio and Design Center in the Windgate Art and Design District, made possible by over $40m in donations from the Windgate Charitable Support Foundation. 

  • Creative hub: The 154,000 sq-ft center is equipped with state-of-the-art facilities that will provide students with a wide range of creative outlets such as studio art programs, graphic design programs, and the new graduate Master of Design degree.
  • Grand opening: Stop by for a coffee at the Arsaga's Café to catch a glimpse of student-designed items from ceramics, photography, drawings, and more, and mark your calendars for the Grand Opening event to celebrate the new center on Saturday, May 6. 

Read more about the art school's new facility HERE.

posts.title: 25,000+ Thank You Northwest Arkansas!
posts.content:
NWA Daily has surpassed 25,000 subscribers! We're grateful to be part of this growing community that makes living in our unique corner of Arkansas so enjoyable!

  • Why we do it: We love calling attention to the businesses, nonprofits, artists, and culture creators that make NWA one of America's most exciting places to be, and we want everyone who lives here to feel like they can be a tourist in their own hometown!
  • Let's keep going: If you love NWA Daily and want to help us keep curating great content to keep you up to date and connected in NWA, become a Fan of NWA Daily, and you'll also gain access to exclusive giveaways!

You can also stay informed with NWA Daily through our Instagram HERE.

posts.title: Highway Improvements on the Horizon for NWA
posts.content:
Prepare yourself for slower traffic! From widening roads to replacing bridges, road crews are gearing up for several major projects across Northwest Arkansas.

  • The long haul: AR-DOT and the city of Rogers are joining forces to widen Hwy 71B between Dixieland Rd and 8th St with a 12-ft center turning lane, upgrades to several intersections, and new sidewalks. The project could take up to 6 years to complete.
  • Under the bridge: Other work this year includes improvements to Hwy 59, adding passing lanes between Sulphur Springs and Decatur, and replacing the decades-old Hwy 59 bridge that crosses the Illinois River with two new spans.

Find more information HERE.

posts.title: What Will You Whisper To The Listening Forest At Crystal Bridges?
posts.content:
Listening Forest, created by artist Rafael Lozano-Hemmer, will return to Crystal Bridges, providing another opportunity to enjoy this one-of-a-kind collision of art and technology that immerses visitors in a poetic and interactive experience with the forest.

  • Your response:  Each section of the exhibition is responsive to different interactions; for instance, add your heartbeat to an array of 3,000 lightbulbs, control giant light figures, and leave a voice recording that will join a chorus of echoes left by other forest visitors.
  • Dates and rates: The forest will be open every Wednesday-Sunday evening from Mar 1 - May 28. Prices range from $15 to $27, and kids 18 and under are free. 

Plan your visit to the Listening Forest HERE.

node.content:
After a week's worth of snow and ice began to melt, the Washington County Fairgrounds turned into quite the mud pit, but that didn't stop nearly a thousand local beer enthusiasts from descending upon the Washington County Fairgrounds for the 2023 Frost Fest.

The winter beer festival, presented by Fossil Cover Brewing Co, brought over 55 breweries from across eight states to Fayetteville, where they got to highlight and share samples of their best brews.

A fleet of local food trucks rolled out with great eats for festivalgoers. Local artisans and businesses came to the event to connect with the public and display their products and services, and rocking out on stage were The Phlegms, Vintage Pistol, and Nick Shoulders & Okay Crawdad.

Beyond enjoying great beer and local businesses, it was a blast getting to see friends from all over Northwest Arkansas gathering to raise a glass to good times and great beer with big smiles on their faces.

Great work Fossil Cove. We can't wait for next year!
node.title: Frost Fest 2023 Photo Recap

node.content:
Heirloom at the 1907 is a hidden gem located in the heart of Downtown Rogers. Tucked away in the Onyx Headquarters, this restaurant is a true oasis for foodies and those seeking a unique dining experience. From the moment you make your reservation, you know you're in for something special.

The atmosphere of Heirloom is truly one-of-a-kind. Danielle Ribuado and her team have mastered the art of hospitality, making sure that every single detail is taken care of. From the playlist in the background, to the personalized service, they have created an environment where you can truly relax and enjoy your meal.

But the real star of the show is the food. Chef Jason Paul has created a rotating prix fixe menu that takes you on a culinary journey. Every 4-6 weeks, the menu changes, giving diners the opportunity to experience something new and exciting with each visit. The restaurant seats only 20 people and is open for reservations only 3-4 nights a week. This ensures that each patron receives the highest quality experience possible.

Reservations for Heirloom drop on the 15th of each month, and they book up quickly. If you're unable to secure a reservation, you can always join the waitlist. But trust me, the wait is well worth it.

As soon as you step through the doors of Heirloom, you're transported to a different world. The atmosphere is intimate and cozy, with a warm and inviting ambiance. The staff is attentive and friendly, making sure that you have everything you need to enjoy your meal.

The food is absolutely outstanding. Chef Jason Paul has created a menu that is both innovative and delicious. The flavors are bold and complex, and the presentation is beautiful. Each course is thoughtfully curated, and the progression of flavors is expertly executed.

The prix fixe menu changes every 4-6 weeks, which means that each visit is a new and exciting experience. You never know what culinary creations will be on the menu, but you can be sure that they will be delicious. The variety of flavors and textures is truly amazing, and it's a pleasure to see how Chef Jason Paul is able to take simple ingredients and elevate them to a new level.

The restaurant seats only 20 people, which means that it's an intimate and cozy dining experience. The small size of the restaurant also ensures that each patron receives the highest quality experience possible. The service is personalized and attentive, and the staff is always happy to answer any questions you may have.

In conclusion, Heirloom at the 1907 is a hidden gem that is not to be missed. The atmosphere, the food, and the service are all outstanding, and it's a pleasure to dine in such a unique and special place. If you're looking for a truly memorable dining experience, make sure to book a reservation at Heirloom.
node.title: Unforgettable Dining at Heirloom at the 1907: A Hidden Gem in Downtown Rogers, Arkansas

node.content:
Northwest Arkansas is leading the state in many ways with its active plans for clean energy, its elevating tech scene, its strong foothold in advanced air mobility, and its mountain biking infrastructure. Among the array of reasons NWA is a great place to be, the region is also making moves to be known for its approach to holistic health. 

Photo courtesy of Andrea Piacquadio

Already, institutions like the University of Health and Performance, the Children's Safety Center, and the Whole Health Institute create environments where the priority and emphasis are on the health of the whole person. The region's latest endeavor to make NWA an epicenter of holistic health is the Alice L. Walton School of Medicine, which is working to combine conventional medicine with integrative techniques and principles. Emotional and mental health is top of mind right now for many people and is an essential part of the well-rounded nature of a healthy community. 

Photo courtesy of Tirachard Kumtanom

While new initiatives are happening, there are already several organizations in NWA for counseling and therapy of all kinds. One of the hardest things sometimes, we think, is how many options there are. So the team at NWA Daily has done some research to narrow down 13 counseling options in the region to create a resource for your mental and emotional health journey.

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

In order by location:

1. Psychology and Counseling Associates

1 W. Sunbridge Dr., Fayetteville

5434 W Walsh Ln., Rogers

Psychology and Counseling Associates has been voted Best Mental Health Clinic for 10 years in a row. It has an office in Fayetteville and Rogers and offers services for ADHD/Learning Difficulties, Alcohol Use Disorder, Anxiety, Depression, Marital Therapy, PTSD, Sexual Health, Eating Disorders, and more. 

Fayetteville: 479.443.5575

Rogers: 479.442.2311

2. Talk Center Counseling Services

130 N College Ave, Fayetteville

Talk Center Counseling strives to help people find their sense of wholeness. Their licensed professional counselors and social service workers serve adults, families, teens, and children. Talk Center Counseling also offers group therapy for teenage girls and a yoga group for those suffering from anxiety.

479.396.8806

3. The Joshua Center

3680 N. Investment Dr, Fayetteville

2105 S. 54th St, Rogers

920 S. Caroline St, Siloam Springs

The Joshua Center offers individual adult therapy, therapy for children, adolescents, and families, couples therapy, pre-marital counseling, and discernment work. The center utilizes different approaches such as emotionally-focused therapy, play therapy, EMDR, brain spotting, and others. 

Fayetteville: 479.435.9356

Rogers: 479.268.4557

Siloam Springs: 479.373.2377

4. Midtown Counseling

1845 Green Acres Rd, Fayetteville

 Midtown Counseling provides counseling services and specialized evaluations to individuals, families, and groups. They accept most major insurance providers and are certified by the Arkansas Board of Examiners in Counseling, the National Board of Certified Counselors, and the American Counseling Association.

479.957.8546

Photo courtesy of cottonbro

5. Pinnacle Counseling 

5500 W Pinnacle Pointe Dr, Rogers

Pinnacle Counseling has been serving the Rogers area for 15 plus years with client-centered approaches to anxiety, depression, marriage and family counseling, etc. Pinnacle Counseling counselors help their clients find empowerment and clarity to achieve their wellness goals. 

479.282.2443

6. Oaks Counseling

6815 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Oaks Counseling is a group of trained and certified counselors with decades of combined experience who are fully equipped to help you process whatever it is you need to move toward a healthier life. 

7. Professional Counseling Services of NWA

6801 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Professional Counseling Services of NWA specialize in individual counseling, stress management, clinical hypnosis, and professional life coaching. At Professional Counseling Services of NWA, you are the expert of your own life, collaborating with an expert in counseling to find solution-focused, individualized goals and treatments for your issues. 

479.799.5577

8. Brookway Counseling

801 Carlton St, Springdale

Brookway Counseling has a team of qualified and experienced counselors specializing in depression and anxiety counseling, ADHD, EMDR therapy, Christian counseling, psychological testing, eating disorders, marriage and family counseling, and online teletherapy.

479.255.5414

9. NWA Premier Therapy

2103 S 54th St, Rogers

NWA Premier Therapy specializes in trauma-focused counseling, though they also offer play therapy, therapy for those struggling with HSP issues, therapy for LGBTQIA+ individuals, grief counseling, and much more.

479.372.7446

479.389.8188 (text)

Photo courtesy of SHVETS

10. Fresh Roots Counseling

3901 W Financial Pkwy, Rogers

Fresh Roots Family Counseling has been serving the NWA community since 1995. They have a team of 20+ licensed professional counselors specializing in many therapy areas. Some techniques that make Fresh Roots stand out are Emotion-Focused couples therapy, EMDR, play therapy, co-parenting counseling, and Sexual Addiction Therapy.

479.986.8655

11. Bentonville Counseling Collective

2104 SE 14th St, Bentonville

Bentonville Counseling Collective offers counseling services to all those wanting to make a positive change in their lives. They specialize in relationship counseling, gender transition counseling, expressive arts therapy, therapy for therapists, telehealth video counseling, and trauma-informed therapy.

479.310.6850

12. Creative Counseling Center

902 McClain Rd, Bentonville

The counselors of the Creative Counseling Center of NWA have created a space of casual, confidential, and collaborative conversation to aid you on your healing journey. They offer services to individuals and couples for a wide variety of issues. 

479.364.0075

13. Soul Talk Therapy

900 SE 5th St, Bentonville

Soul Talk Therapy is in a quaint, comfortable space with dedicated counselors cultivating safe environments to explore thoughts, feelings, and experiences without any threat of judgment. 

479.888.5546

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

If you're still looking to find free and affordable counseling near you, or you want to learn more about what is available, check out opencounseling.com. For tips on how to find a counselor fit for you in NWA, read this blog post from Fresh Roots Family Counseling.
node.title: Whole Health, Counseling & Therapy in NWA

node.content:
There are very few people on the planet who do not stop and acknowledge an aircraft that passes by overhead. Even if it’s as brief a moment as one second, people notice and almost ubiquitously harbor some fascination with flying objects in the sky. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

It seems like such a distant place — the sky — but it really is more approachable than people realize. The Wright Brothers saw to that with their first flight in 1903. Aviation has come such a long way in just over a century, as now, flying is something anyone can do with training and help from local flight schools. 

Northwest Arkansas is slowly becoming one of the hottest spots for aviation in the United States – specifically recreational aviation, because of its accessibility and the ideal environment that this part of the country provides. Recreational aviation, or backcountry aviation, has put NWA and the Ozarks on the map for many pilots, almost exclusively due to the initiative at Fly Oz, the region’s recreational aviation arm based in Bentonville. 

Photo courtesy of Fly Oz 

Fly Oz and aviation enthusiasts in this part of the country have worked with private land owners to connect pilots and non-pilots to activities and experiences through a network of grass airstrips on land otherwise unreachable. Director of Fly Oz, Chip Gibbons, said people who come to fly in NWA have a bigger picture of the region than those who come mountain bike in the area for a week, which makes sense. Through initiatives to get people in the air and to different parts of the region and state, NWA has become a base in a network of adventure. 

“Here, our focus has really been on what you do once you have arrived,” Gibbons said. “Get out of the airplane, take in the scenery, do some fishing, do some paddling, you know, whatever lights you up.” 

Flying in and out of the backcountry is what the region is primarily known for in the world of aviation, but it also has the ideal infrastructure for learning to fly at any level and in any air space. Due to the lower density altitude here allowing airplanes to perform better, and the local flight schools being some of the most resourceful and approachable around, there aren’t many places better than NWA to learn to fly for fun.

“It’s almost the perfect little environment to do this in,” Gibbons said. “I don’t know what I would change about where we live that would make it better.” 

The two leading flight schools in the area are Summit Aviation in Bentonville and ARH Aviation in Springdale. Summit Aviation is the fixed-based operator at Thaden Field, a municipal and private jet airport in downtown Bentonville. ARH Aviation is a premier aviation supplier located at the Springdale municipal general aviation airport. Whether you train through Summit Aviation, participate in its OZ1 Flying Club department or learn to fly with experts at ARH Aviation, the sky is yours to conquer. Our region is yours to behold like never before. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

Chad Cox, the president of Summit Aviation, told Talk Business & Politics that Flying in NWA “isn’t just about getting from Point A to Point B.” It’s also about connecting to what’s happening in all the areas of recreation and leisure in NWA, adding to the overall adventure. 

Fly Oz and Fly AHR offer discovery flights and charter flights of different kinds for you to see and explore the beauty of our region in a whole new way. The scenic flights are also perfect for trying out how it feels to be in the sky. Like so many in recent years, who knows, you might immediately decide that becoming a pilot is for you. 

Becoming a private pilot through Summit Aviation in Bentonville or ARH Aviation in Springdale costs in the ballpark of $10,000 after you purchase course materials, pay for exam fees, aircraft rental, and ground and air instruction. Though it’s a bit pricey, there are scholarships out there to help. 

Whether you have a desire to become a pilot or not, there is a whole perspective of our region from the sky just waiting for you. So go check it out, and you won’t be disappointed. 

For more information about Fly Oz, click HERE. 

For more information about OZ1, click HERE. 

For more information about flight training through Summit Aviation, click HERE. 

For more information about flight training through ARH Aviation, click HERE.
node.title: Flying In The Ozarks

node.content:
The Jones Center is another one of those special amenities in Northwest Arkansas that if you don’t know about it, you should. The center is 220.000 square feet of space, deemed as a destination for growth. Bernice Jones, a driving force in the region, gifted the center to Springdale 25 years ago with the promise that “All are welcome.” 

 

The center is a recreation, education, and event center founded with a mission to strengthen and enrich the community, celebrate culture, and be a conduit for service and thriving collaboration. The vision for The Jones Center has always been that the community would be a part of it and make it their own. And with people doing just that, the center is continuously growing and adapting to the ever-changing region. 

 

The Jones Center and its 52-acre campus are currently in a phase of re-imagining. A project is brewing to “elevate The Jones Center’s core indoor recreation amenities with sustainability in mind while complimenting and blending with the Springdale Downtown Revitalization Master Plan.” 


﻿

 

Right now, the Jones Campus includes The Jones Center and the Center for Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops. The Jones Center has amenities such as an ice arena, pools, fitness center, gymnasium, runway bike park, and more. The Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops is home to more than 40 nonprofit organizations serving NWA, professional office and meeting space, and the Harvey Jones Education Building. 


 

The vision for the campus consists of bold changes that include introducing new open spaces and plazas, incorporating art pieces that pique interest and act as culturally inspired place-makers, and creating an interconnected system of hard and soft surface trails that tie The Jones Campus to downtown and beyond. The vision has a multi-layered approach with theme-based programming. The themes are wellness and recreation, gardens and ecology, community and gathering, arts and culture, and campus support. 


 

The project’s goals include creating another destination in NWA where people gather, “recreate, celebrate, and build a stronger sense of community,” expanding on Bernice’s ethos of welcoming all. The design elements of the project include the Meto Spine, Emma Ave. Connector + JTL Courtyard, The Community Common, OZ Play Area, Fitness Pad, OZ Gardens + Expanded Action Sports, and Woven Links + Patchwork Parking + JTL Plaza. 

 

Click HERE to learn all about it.
node.title: The Jones Campus: A Campus Adapting With A Continued Vision For Welcoming All
